case_vignette: A 12-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with a swollen and painful knee. He says that he was exploring with his friends when he tripped and hit his knee against the ground. He didn't feel like he hit it very hard but it started swelling and becoming very painful. His mom reports that he has always been prone to bleeding from very minor trauma and that others in the family have had similar problems. Based on clinical suspicion a coagulation panel was obtained showing a prothrombin time (PT) of 10 seconds (normal range 9-11 seconds), a partial thromboplastin time (PTT) of 45 seconds (normal 20-35 seconds), and a normal ristocetin cofactor assay (equivalent to bleeding time). Mixing tests with factor IX and XI do not show complementation, but mixing with factor VIII reverses the coagulation abnormality.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Hematology and Oncology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask simple 1 line questions, one question at a time. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
My knee is really swollen and it hurts a lot.
How long has your knee been swollen and painful?
It started swelling and becoming very painful right after I tripped and hit it on the ground today.
Did you hear a pop when you injured your knee, or have you noticed any instability or difficulty bearing weight on that leg?
No, I didn't hear a pop when I injured my knee, and I didn't notice it being unstable or hard to put weight on.
Is there any visible bruising or cuts on the knee, and do you have any known allergies to medications?
There's no mention of any bruising, cuts, or allergies to medications in my case.
Have you taken any medication for the pain or swelling?
No, I haven't taken any medication for it.
Have you had any similar injuries or joint issues in the past?
Yes, I've always been prone to bleeding from very minor injuries.
Do you have any family history of bleeding disorders?
Yes, others in my family have had similar problems with bleeding.
Final Diagnosis: Hemarthrosis likely due to an underlying bleeding disorder.
